publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in ŠorčuqStadthöhleduring T III Š 72.09

sourceDesc.p: Transcription and references have been transferred from the "Text and Reference Database of the Tocharian A Language" (Gerd Carling Lund University) (funded by the Bank of Sweden Tercentenary Foundation and SCAS).
Transcription and translation are based on .

seg.seg: Presumably out of love he touched the girl and the mechanism broke down. Out of shame the painter killed himself: he is hanging
er tötete sich selbst
he killed himself
Presumably out of love he touched the girl and the mechanism broke down. Out of shame the painter killed himself: he is hanging from the nail—look, o good ones!
from the nail – look, o good ones! 1. The people, too, who saw the painting and took it for real say:
Alas! It was really a damage! Thereupon the master mechanic went to the king and this matter to the king he told [saying]:
Oh lord, there came a painter from another country [and] he came down to my house, now because of shame
Es kam ein Maler eines anderen Landes, in meinem Haus war er abgestiegen. Der hat sich jetzt aus Scham selbst getötet.
A painter from another country came [along], in my house he put up. He has now killed himself out of shame.
he has killed himself! The lord should know this. The king, however, who believed him, sent the minister to (look into) this [matter].
The lord should know this. (cf 12; 261)
er tötete sich selbst
he killed himself
Thereupon the ministers and noblemen, whoever had seen the picture, for everybody it was really the master painter.
Therefore they cried all together. Thereupon the mechanic says to the people: Useless(?) is your crying, bring my axe!
Deshalb weinten sie alle insgesamt. Darauf sagte der Mechaniker zu den Menschen: "Weinet doch nicht, holet (mir) eine Axt herbei: Nach Zerschneidung des Strickes tragt diesen fort!"
Therefore they were all crying together. Thereupon the mechanic said to the people: "Don't cry, bring me an axe: the string, having been cut, carry away!"
After having cut off the rope, carry this one away. Thereupon the mechanic wanted to cut off the rope with the axe.
Darauf wollte der Mechaniker mit der Axt den Strick zerschneiden.
Thereupon the mechanic intended to cut the rope with the axe.
Thereupon the painter stood forward and said to the master mechanic: || In the K.-tune: || Do not do it, do not do it, do not be sad,

Tu's nicht, tu's nicht, sei nicht traurig, o Mechaniker, [zerstöre] nicht deine Wand, zerstöre nicht mein makelloses Gemälde, sieh sorgfältig zu, [o] Freund, beachte zuvor die Regel: [Ein] anderes ist das Gemälde, [ein] anderes der Maler, warum weißt du [das] nicht?

Don't do it, don't do it, don't be sad, oh mechanic, don't [destroy] your wall, don't destroy my faultless painting, watch carefully, [my] friend, mind first the rule: [an]other [thing] is the painting, [an]other [thing is] the painter, why don't you know [this]?
oh mechanic, do not destroy your wall, do not destroy my painting without defect. Watch carefully, you fool/friend(?)
first observe the rule: one thing is the painting, another thing is the painter, why don’t you know that? 1. || All people that have seen this
being amazed they laugh. Thus a figure of wood and painting, too, (calls forth) the love [and] affection of the living beings,

p.note: The translation is largely based on 12-13, and .

div.p: Edition8-9. Siegling's personal copy of p. 8 p. 9.

list.item: a1 ypā : #1b tuṅkyo aśśi|=śśi tsit , śomināṃ ; wekat yantär|yaṃtär , cam kipyo : #1c sruksāt āñcäm , säm pekant ; läṅkäṣ a2 ṣpinac , pälkāc kraṃś : 1 || #1d wrasañ penu cam peke pälkoräṣ yneś_(TA)|yneś pälskaṃ yāmuṣ träṅki(ñc) a3 hai_(TA)|hai wäṣpā kāryap tāk || tmäṣ yaṃtrācāre käṣṣi_(TA)|käṣṣi lānt«a»c kälk cam wram lānt ākṣiññā|ā(kṣi)|ññā a4 nātäk ālu ypeṣi pekant yeṣ ñi waṣtā kākärpu ṣeṣ säm tāpärk kip ṣärmaṣi|ṣä(rma)|{ṣ}i a5 ṣñi āñcäm sasrukāt täṣ nātkis kärsor tāṣ wäl penu perāk_(TA)|perāk āmāśās cam wram lkātsi|(lkā)|(tsi) a6 lyu tmäṣ āmāśāñ ypeṣiñi wrasañ kus|kuss ats ne cam peke pälkānt p_ukis yneś_(TA)|yneś yneś_(TA)|yneś pe(kant) b1 (käṣṣi) tāk tämyo cem pukāk|p_ukāk tsārtar tmäṣ yaṃtrācāre wrassac träṅkäṣ maśkaṃ śercär {ṣ}u pkāmā(c-ñi) b2 por(a){t} sparp kärṣtoräṣ caṣ pre lo pkāmāc tmäṣ yaṃtrācāre poratyo sparp|svarp kärṣnātsi päknāṣāt tmäṣ|(tmä)|ṣ b3 pekant pākär lantu yaṃtrācāreṃ käṣṣinac träṅkäṣ || kuswaṃ || # mar yat mar yat ; mar slākkär|slā|kkär b4 naṣt ; yaṃtrācāre : #1a mar ṣñi poṣi ; mar ñi peke ; ka{t} yat sne maṅk : #1b pälkār nar ṣu ; āne(ñci) b5 neṣ ; ṣotre pyāmtsār : #1c ālak peke ; ālak pekant ; kuyal|kyal mā_(TA)|mā kärsnāt : || #1d täm pälkoräṣ puk wras(añ) b6 añumāski nāṃtsuṣ karyeñc || taṃne wkänyo orṣi pekeṣi penu arämpāt wrasaśśi tuṅk|tuṅ= kāpñune aräṣ|(a)|(räṣ)

Translations from [[Peyrot, ToSu]]
Lines Translation Pages
a1-2 Presumably out of love he touched the girl and the mechanism broke down. Out of shame the painter killed himself: he is hanging from the nail—look, o good ones! 279
a5 The lord should know this. (cf [[Sieg, Übers. I]]: 12; [[Pinault 2008]]: 261) 223


Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]
Lines Translation Pages
a1 er tötete sich selbst 309, fn. 2
a4-5 Es kam ein Maler eines anderen Landes, in meinem Haus war er abgestiegen. Der hat sich jetzt aus Scham selbst getötet. 316
a5 er tötete sich selbst 309, fn. 2
b1-2 Deshalb weinten sie alle insgesamt. Darauf sagte der Mechaniker zu den Menschen: "Weinet doch nicht, holet (mir) eine Axt herbei: Nach Zerschneidung des Strickes tragt diesen fort!" 92-3
b2 Darauf wollte der Mechaniker mit der Axt den Strick zerschneiden. 148
b3-5 Tu's nicht, tu's nicht, sei nicht traurig, o Mechaniker, [zerstöre] nicht deine Wand, zerstöre nicht mein makelloses Gemälde, sieh sorgfältig zu, [o] Freund, beachte zuvor die Regel: [Ein] anderes ist das Gemälde, [ein] anderes der Maler, warum weißt du [das] nicht? 190, 431


in line b2 [[Carling, DThTA]]: 169 has kärṣnātsi instead of the above kärṣtātsi (TI). The correct form has n, not t; but such differences with the standard edition should be noted (MP).

a5, täṣ nātkis kärsor tāṣ, translation as above, or as passive “this should be known by mylord” (following [[Carling, DThTA]]: 172)? (TI)

for the last word of a4/first word of a5, [[Carling, DThTA]]: 181 has ṣu(rma)‹ṣ›i (TI)

b2: [[TochSprR(A)]]: 9 read kärṣtātsi. (BK)

a1 Presumably out of love he touched the girl and the mechanism broke down. Out of shame the painter killed himself: he is hanging a2 from the nail – look, o good ones! 1. The people, too, who saw the painting and took it for real say: a3 Alas! It was really a damage! Thereupon the master mechanic went to the king and this matter to the king he told [saying]: a4 Oh lord, there came a painter from another country [and] he came down to my house, now because of shame a5 he has killed himself! The lord should know this. The king, however, who believed him, sent the minister to (look into) this [matter]. a6 Thereupon the ministers and noblemen, whoever had seen the picture, for everybody it was really the master painter. b1 Therefore they cried all together. Thereupon the mechanic says to the people: Useless(?) is your crying, bring my axe! b2 After having cut off the rope, carry this one away. Thereupon the mechanic wanted to cut off the rope with the axe. b3 Thereupon the painter stood forward and said to the master mechanic: || In the K.-tune: || Do not do it, do not do it, do not be sad, b4 oh mechanic, do not destroy your wall, do not destroy my painting without defect. Watch carefully, you fool/friend(?) b5 first observe the rule: one thing is the painting, another thing is the painter, why don’t you know that? 1. || All people that have seen this b6 being amazed they laugh. Thus a figure of wood and painting, too, (calls forth) the love [and] affection of the living beings,

The translation is largely based on [[Sieg, Übers. I]]: 12-13, and [[Carling, DThTA]].

b3. The tune has 4x12 syllables, rhythm 4/4/4.

a1 ypā : tuṅkyo =śśi tsi«_t»\ śomināṃ weka_t\ yaṃ_t_ar ca_m\ kipyo : sruksā_t\ āñcä_m\ _s_am pekan_t\ _l_aṅ_k_a[_ṣ\] a2 ṣpinacä\ _p_alkācä\ kraṃśä\ : 1 || wrasañ penu ca_m\ peke _p_alko_r_a_ṣ\ yneś _p_alskaṃ yāmu_ṣ\ t_r_aṅki (–) a3 hai wäṣpā kāryap tā_k\ || _t_m_a_ṣ\ yaṃtrācāre _k_aṣṣi lān_t\c _k_a_l_k\ ca_m\ wra_m\ lān_t\ ā (–) a4 -ññā nā_t_a_k\ ālu ypeṣi pekan_t\ ye_ṣ\ ñi waṣtā kā_k_arpu ṣe_ṣ\ _s_am tā_p_ar_k\ ki_p _ṣ_a – a5 -pi ṣñi āñcä_m\ sasrukā_t\ _t_aṣ nātki_s\ _k_arsor tā_ṣ\ wäl penu perā_k\ āmāśās ca_m\ wra_m\ – a6 – lyu _t_m_a_ṣ\ āmāśāñä\ ypeṣiñi wrasañ kuss ats ne ca_m\ peke _p_alkān_t\ p_uki_s\ yneś yneś [p]e – – b1 – – [t]ā_k\ _t_amyo ce_m\ p_ukā_k\ tsārta_r\ _t_m_a_ṣ\ yaṃtrācāre wrassac t_r_aṅ_k_a_ṣ\ maśkaṃ śercä_r\ pu pkāmā (– –) b2 [por]·[_s\] spar_p\ _k_arṣto_r_a_ṣ\ caṣ pre lo pkāmācä\ _t_m_aṣ yaṃtrācāre poratyo svar_p\ _k_arṣnātsi _p_aknāṣā_t\ – b3 -ṣ pekan_t\ pā_k_ar lantu yaṃtrācāreṃ _k_aṣṣinacä\ t_r_aṅ_k_a_ṣ\ || kuswaṃ || mar ya_t\ mar ya_t\ mar slā- b4 -[k]_k_ar na_ṣ_t\ yaṃtrā«cā»re : mar ṣñi poṣi mar ñi peke kan ya_t\ sne maṅ_k\ : _p_alkār nar ṣu āne (–) b5 neṣ ṣotre pyāmtsā_r\ : ālak peke ālak pekan_t\ kyal mā _k_arsnā_t\ : || _t_am _p_alko_r_a_ṣ\ pu_k\ wra[s]· (–) b6 añumāski nāṃtsuṣ karyeñcä\ || taṃne w_k_anyo orṣi pekeṣi «pe»nu a_r_ampāt wrasaśśi tuṅ= kāpñune (–)

div.p: in line <citedRange>169</citedRange></bibl> has <hi>kärṣnātsi</hi> instead of the above <hi>kärṣtātsi</hi> (TI). The correct form has n, not t; but such differences with the standard edition should be noted (MP).</p><p><ref type="ms" target="__a5,"/><hi>täṣ nātkis kärsor tāṣ</hi>, translation as above, or as passive “this should be known by mylord” (following <bibl><title corresp="ref:carlingetal2009"/><citedRange>172</citedRange></bibl>)? (TI)</p><p>for the last word of <ref type="ms" target="__a4"/>/first word of <ref type="ms" target="__a5"/>, <bibl><title corresp="ref:carlingetal2009"/><citedRange>181</citedRange></bibl> has <hi>ṣu(rma)‹ṣ›i</hi> (TI)</p><p><ref type="ms" target="__b2:"/><bibl><title corresp="ref:siegandsiegling1921"/><citedRange>9</citedRange></bibl> read <hi>kärṣtātsi</hi>. (BK)</p></project_comment>
